findings.title: GFM table parsing has overhead
findings.description: Enabling GFM (GitHub-Flavored Markdown) adds ~50% overhead for table parsing due to extension loading.

findings.title: Parsing vs rendering ratio
findings.description: Markdown parsing is fast compared to rendering. Most time is spent in layout and buffer operations.

findings.title: Single element measurement is extremely fast
findings.description: Measuring individual elements takes <5 microseconds regardless of content.

findings.title: Container measurement scales linearly with child count
findings.description: Measuring a flat container takes ~1.5s per child element.

findings.title: Fast-path optimization for scrollable containers
findings.description: Scrollable containers with >50 children use sampling, making measurement O(1) instead of O(n).

findings.title: Nested containers add depth overhead
findings.description: Deeply nested containers require recursive measurement but remain fast for typical depths.

findings.title: Diff scales linearly with buffer size
findings.description: Buffer diff time scales approximately linearly with total cell count.

findings.title: Change percentage has minimal impact on diff time
findings.description: Diff time is dominated by cell comparison, not result collection. 0% vs 100% difference has similar scan time.

findings.title: Dirty row tracking reduces scan overhead
findings.description: DualBuffer dirty tracking scans only modified rows, improving performance for localized changes.

findings.title: Wide characters add overhead to diff
findings.description: Wide character handling adds ~30% overhead to diff operations due to continuation cell checks.

findings.title: GFM table parsing has overhead
findings.description: Enabling GFM (GitHub-Flavored Markdown) adds ~50% overhead for table parsing due to extension loading.

findings.title: Parsing vs rendering ratio
findings.description: Markdown parsing is fast compared to rendering. Most time is spent in layout and buffer operations.

findings.title: pointInBounds is extremely fast
findings.description: Single point-in-bounds check takes ~1 nanosecond. Can perform millions per frame.

findings.title: All geometry operations are sub-microsecond
findings.description: clipBounds and boundsIntersect are comparable in cost to pointInBounds.

findings.title: Object creation in clampToBounds adds overhead
findings.description: clampToBounds creates a new Point object, making it slightly slower than pure checks.

findings.title: Simple components render fast
findings.description: Basic components (text, button, input) render in under 0.1ms. Component overhead is minimal.

findings.title: Nesting depth has moderate impact
findings.description: Each level of nesting adds small overhead. 5 levels is ~50% slower than 3 levels.

findings.title: Tables scale linearly with rows
findings.description: Table rendering time scales approximately linearly with row count.

findings.title: Buffer string output is efficient
findings.description: Converting rendered buffer to string representation is fast even for large buffers.

findings.title: Hit testing scales with tree traversal depth
findings.description: Flat trees are fastest. Deep nesting adds overhead for each level traversed.

findings.title: Wide trees have higher traversal cost
findings.description: Trees with many siblings at each level require checking more elements.

findings.title: Element position in flat list affects hit time
findings.description: First-match returns quickly. Elements at the end require full traversal.

findings.title: Hit testing is fast enough for 60fps
findings.description: 100 random hit tests on large tree takes ~2-3ms, well within 16.67ms frame budget.

findings.title: Single element measurement is extremely fast
findings.description: Measuring individual elements takes <5 microseconds regardless of content.

findings.title: Container measurement scales linearly with child count
findings.description: Measuring a flat container takes ~1.5s per child element.

findings.title: Fast-path optimization for scrollable containers
findings.description: Scrollable containers with >50 children use sampling, making measurement O(1) instead of O(n).

findings.title: Nested containers add depth overhead
findings.description: Deeply nested containers require recursive measurement but remain fast for typical depths.

findings.title: Flowchart parsing is fastest
findings.description: Flowchart parsing is faster than sequence and class diagrams due to simpler syntax.

findings.title: Layout is O(n*e) complexity
findings.description: Layout calculation scales with nodes and edges. Complex graphs with subgraphs take longer.

findings.title: Rendering dominates graph processing time
findings.description: Full rendering (parse + layout + convert + render) is significantly slower than parsing alone.

findings.title: Contiguous spans are much faster than scattered
findings.description: Contiguous cell updates benefit from span grouping, reducing cursor movements.

findings.title: Full screen updates are within frame budget
findings.description: Rendering all 4800 cells (120x40) takes ~2-3ms, well under 16.67ms budget.

findings.title: Color mode has minimal performance impact
findings.description: Truecolor, 256-color, and 16-color modes have similar generation times.

findings.title: Style changes add overhead
findings.description: Frequent style changes (bold, italic, colors) increase output generation time.

findings.title: Early termination provides significant speedup
findings.description: Finding first element vs last element shows the benefit of depth-first early return.

findings.title: Tree shape affects traversal time
findings.description: Deep trees traverse faster than wide trees with same node count due to fewer siblings to check.

findings.title: collectElements with array reuse is faster
findings.description: Reusing a result array avoids allocation overhead in hot paths.

findings.title: isDescendant is O(n) worst case
findings.description: Descendant check requires full tree traversal when element is not found.

findings.title: Traversal scales linearly with node count
findings.description: Full traversal time correlates with total nodes in tree.

findings.title: Kitty encoding is faster than Sixel
findings.description: Kitty protocol encodes 5.9x faster than Sixel at 256x256. Kitty avoids palette quantization overhead.

findings.title: RLE compression improves Sixel encoding
findings.description: RLE compression makes Sixel encoding 1.6x faster by reducing output size.

findings.title: RGB format slightly faster than RGBA
findings.description: Kitty RGB format (no alpha) encodes slightly faster and produces smaller output.

findings.title: Diff scales linearly with buffer size
findings.description: Buffer diff time scales approximately linearly with total cell count.

findings.title: Change percentage has minimal impact on diff time
findings.description: Diff time is dominated by cell comparison, not result collection. 0% vs 100% difference has similar scan time.

findings.title: Dirty row tracking reduces scan overhead
findings.description: DualBuffer dirty tracking scans only modified rows, improving performance for localized changes.

findings.title: Wide characters add overhead to diff
findings.description: Wide character handling adds ~30% overhead to diff operations due to continuation cell checks.

findings.title: Kitty encoding is faster than Sixel
findings.description: Kitty protocol encodes 4.7x faster than Sixel at 256x256. Kitty avoids palette quantization overhead.

findings.title: RLE compression improves Sixel encoding
findings.description: RLE compression makes Sixel encoding 2.1x faster by reducing output size.

findings.title: RGB format slightly faster than RGBA

findings.title: Hit testing scales with tree traversal depth
findings.description: Flat trees are fastest. Deep nesting adds overhead for each level traversed.

findings.title: Wide trees have higher traversal cost
findings.description: Trees with many siblings at each level require checking more elements.

findings.title: Element position in flat list affects hit time
findings.description: First-match returns quickly. Elements at the end require full traversal.

findings.title: Hit testing is fast enough for 60fps
findings.description: 100 random hit tests on large tree takes ~2-3ms, well within 16.67ms frame budget.

findings.title: Median-cut quantization is expensive
findings.description: Median-cut quantization dominates graphics pipeline time. Use fixed palettes or cache quantization results for static images.

findings.title: Fixed-216 web-safe palette is fast
findings.description: Fixed-216 (web-safe) palette is as fast as fixed-256 and produces consistent results across terminals.

findings.title: Ordered dithering is fastest
findings.description: Ordered (Bayer) dithering is ~2-3x faster than error-diffusion methods while maintaining temporal stability.

findings.title: Blue noise provides best quality
findings.description: Blue noise dithering produces the best visual quality with no visible patterns, at moderate speed.

findings.title: Stable variants have minimal overhead
findings.description: Temporally stable dithering variants (for video) have similar performance to standard versions.

findings.title: Bit depth affects quality, not speed
findings.description: Different bit depths (1-bit B&W to 8-bit color) have similar performance; choose based on output quality needs.

findings.title: Fast-path optimization for scrollable containers
findings.description: Scrollable containers with >50 children use sampling, making measurement O(1) instead of O(n).

findings.title: Nested containers add depth overhead
findings.description: Deeply nested containers require recursive measurement but remain fast for typical depths.

findings.title: Early termination provides significant speedup
findings.description: Finding first element vs last element shows the benefit of depth-first early return.

findings.title: Tree shape affects traversal time
findings.description: Deep trees traverse faster than wide trees with same node count due to fewer siblings to check.

findings.title: collectElements with array reuse is faster
findings.description: Reusing a result array avoids allocation overhead in hot paths.

findings.title: isDescendant is O(n) worst case
findings.description: Descendant check requires full tree traversal when element is not found.

findings.title: Traversal scales linearly with node count
findings.description: Full traversal time correlates with total nodes in tree.

findings.title: Contiguous spans are much faster than scattered
findings.description: Contiguous cell updates benefit from span grouping, reducing cursor movements.

findings.title: Full screen updates are within frame budget
findings.description: Rendering all 4800 cells (120x40) takes ~2-3ms, well under 16.67ms budget.

findings.title: Color mode has minimal performance impact
findings.description: Truecolor, 256-color, and 16-color modes have similar generation times.

findings.title: Style changes add overhead
findings.description: Frequent style changes (bold, italic, colors) increase output generation time.

findings.title: Flowchart parsing is fastest
findings.description: Flowchart parsing is faster than sequence and class diagrams due to simpler syntax.

findings.title: Layout is O(n*e) complexity
findings.description: Layout calculation scales with nodes and edges. Complex graphs with subgraphs take longer.

findings.title: Rendering dominates graph processing time
findings.description: Full rendering (parse + layout + convert + render) is significantly slower than parsing alone.

findings.title: Diff scales linearly with buffer size
findings.description: Buffer diff time scales approximately linearly with total cell count.

findings.title: Change percentage has minimal impact on diff time
findings.description: Diff time is dominated by cell comparison, not result collection. 0% vs 100% difference has similar scan time.

findings.title: Dirty row tracking reduces scan overhead
findings.description: DualBuffer dirty tracking scans only modified rows, improving performance for localized changes.

findings.title: Wide characters add overhead to diff
findings.description: Wide character handling adds ~30% overhead to diff operations due to continuation cell checks.

findings.title: Diff scales linearly with buffer size
findings.description: Buffer diff time scales approximately linearly with total cell count.

findings.title: Change percentage has minimal impact on diff time
findings.description: Diff time is dominated by cell comparison, not result collection. 0% vs 100% difference has similar scan time.

findings.title: Dirty row tracking reduces scan overhead
findings.description: DualBuffer dirty tracking scans only modified rows, improving performance for localized changes.

findings.title: Wide characters add overhead to diff
findings.description: Wide character handling adds ~30% overhead to diff operations due to continuation cell checks.

findings.title: Flowchart parsing is fastest
findings.description: Flowchart parsing is faster than sequence and class diagrams due to simpler syntax.

findings.title: Layout is O(n*e) complexity
findings.description: Layout calculation scales with nodes and edges. Complex graphs with subgraphs take longer.

findings.title: Rendering dominates graph processing time
findings.description: Full rendering (parse + layout + convert + render) is significantly slower than parsing alone.

findings.title: GFM table parsing has overhead
findings.description: Enabling GFM (GitHub-Flavored Markdown) adds ~50% overhead for table parsing due to extension loading.

findings.title: Parsing vs rendering ratio
findings.description: Markdown parsing is fast compared to rendering. Most time is spent in layout and buffer operations.

findings.title: Simple components render fast
findings.description: Basic components (text, button, input) render quickly. DualBuffer allocation dominates for simple elements.

findings.title: Nesting depth has moderate impact
findings.description: Each level of nesting adds small overhead. 5 levels is ~50% slower than 3 levels.

findings.title: Tables scale linearly with rows
findings.description: Table rendering time scales approximately linearly with row count.

findings.title: Buffer string output is efficient
findings.description: Converting rendered buffer to string representation is fast even for large buffers.

findings.title: Kitty encoding is faster than Sixel
findings.description: Kitty protocol encodes 5.5x faster than Sixel at 256x256. Kitty avoids palette quantization overhead.

findings.title: RLE compression improves Sixel encoding
findings.description: RLE compression makes Sixel encoding 1.9x faster by reducing output size.

findings.title: RGB format slightly faster than RGBA
findings.description: Kitty RGB format (no alpha) encodes slightly faster and produces smaller output.

findings.title: Simple components render fast
findings.description: Basic components (text, button, input) render in under 0.1ms. Component overhead is minimal.

findings.title: Tables scale linearly with rows

findings.title: Median-cut quantization is expensive
findings.description: Median-cut quantization dominates graphics pipeline time. Use fixed palettes or cache quantization results for static images.

findings.title: Fixed-216 web-safe palette is fast
findings.description: Fixed-216 (web-safe) palette is as fast as fixed-256 and produces consistent results across terminals.

findings.title: Early termination provides significant speedup

findings.title: Tree shape affects traversal time
findings.description: Deep trees traverse faster than wide trees with same node count due to fewer siblings to check.

findings.title: collectElements with array reuse is faster
findings.description: Reusing a result array avoids allocation overhead in hot paths.

findings.title: isDescendant is O(n) worst case
findings.description: Descendant check requires full tree traversal when element is not found.

findings.title: Traversal scales linearly with node count
findings.description: Full traversal time correlates with total nodes in tree.

findings.title: Kitty encoding is faster than Sixel
findings.description: Kitty protocol encodes 5.7x faster than Sixel at 256x256. Kitty avoids palette quantization overhead.

findings.title: RLE compression improves Sixel encoding
findings.description: RLE compression makes Sixel encoding 1.9x faster by reducing output size.

findings.title: RGB format slightly faster than RGBA
findings.description: Kitty RGB format (no alpha) encodes slightly faster and produces smaller output.

findings.title: Ordered dithering is fastest
findings.description: Ordered (Bayer) dithering is ~2-3x faster than error-diffusion methods while maintaining temporal stability.

findings.title: Blue noise provides best quality
findings.description: Blue noise dithering produces the best visual quality with no visible patterns, at moderate speed.

findings.title: Stable variants have minimal overhead
findings.description: Temporally stable dithering variants (for video) have similar performance to standard versions.

findings.title: Bit depth affects quality, not speed
findings.description: Different bit depths (1-bit B&W to 8-bit color) have similar performance; choose based on output quality needs.

findings.title: Kitty encoding is faster than Sixel
findings.description: Kitty protocol encodes 5.9x faster than Sixel at 256x256. Kitty avoids palette quantization overhead.

findings.title: RLE compression improves Sixel encoding
findings.description: RLE compression makes Sixel encoding 1.7x faster by reducing output size.

findings.title: RGB format slightly faster than RGBA
findings.description: Kitty RGB format (no alpha) encodes slightly faster and produces smaller output.

findings.title: pointInBounds is extremely fast
findings.description: Single point-in-bounds check takes ~1 nanosecond. Can perform millions per frame.

findings.title: All geometry operations are sub-microsecond
findings.description: clipBounds and boundsIntersect are comparable in cost to pointInBounds.

findings.title: Object creation in clampToBounds adds overhead
findings.description: clampToBounds creates a new Point object, making it slightly slower than pure checks.

findings.title: Hit testing scales with tree traversal depth
findings.description: Flat trees are fastest. Deep nesting adds overhead for each level traversed.

findings.title: Wide trees have higher traversal cost
findings.description: Trees with many siblings at each level require checking more elements.

findings.title: Element position in flat list affects hit time
findings.description: First-match returns quickly. Elements at the end require full traversal.

findings.title: Hit testing is fast enough for 60fps
findings.description: 100 random hit tests on large tree takes ~2-3ms, well within 16.67ms frame budget.

findings.title: Kitty encoding is faster than Sixel
findings.description: Kitty protocol encodes 5.0x faster than Sixel at 256x256. Kitty avoids palette quantization overhead.

notes:
[markdown] Markdown component benchmarks. Tests parsing, rendering of various markdown elements including headings, lists, code blocks, tables, and mixed documents.

[content-measurer] Content measurement benchmarks. Tests single element measurement, flat containers (10-500 children), nested containers (various depths), scrollable container fast-path optimization, and mixed element type containers.

[buffer-diff] Buffer diff benchmarks. Tests diff performance across buffer sizes (400-16000 cells), change percentages (0-100%), change patterns (scattered, clustered, row-based), DualBuffer operations, and dirty row tracking effectiveness.

[markdown] Markdown component benchmarks. Tests parsing, rendering of various markdown elements including headings, lists, code blocks, tables, and mixed documents.

[geometry] Geometry utility benchmarks. Tests pointInBounds, clampToBounds, clipBounds, and boundsIntersect at various scales. These are foundational operations used in hit testing, rendering, and viewport management.

[components-rendering] Component rendering benchmarks. Tests individual components, nested layouts, tables, lists, scrollable containers, and full page layouts. ANSI output generation is also measured.

[hit-test] Hit testing benchmarks. Tests element detection across flat trees (10-500 elements), deep trees (5-20 levels), and wide trees (150-1100 elements). Includes miss scenarios and interactive element checks.

[content-measurer] Content measurement benchmarks. Tests single element measurement, flat containers (10-500 children), nested containers (various depths), scrollable container fast-path optimization, and mixed element type containers.

[graph] Graph component and Mermaid diagram benchmarks. Tests parsing (flowchart, sequence, class), layout calculation, conversion to Melker XML, and full rendering pipeline.

[ansi-output] ANSI output generation benchmarks. Tests scattered vs contiguous updates, full screen rendering, style changes, color mode comparisons (truecolor/256/16/none), and span grouping optimization.

[tree-traversal] Tree traversal benchmarks. Tests findElement, hasElement, collectElements, isDescendant, findElementById, and findParentOf across flat trees (100-1000 nodes), deep trees (10-50 levels), and wide balanced trees (150-780 nodes).

[encoding] Encoding benchmarks for Sixel and Kitty protocols. Kitty is faster because it sends raw pixels; Sixel requires palette encoding. Use Kitty when terminal supports it.

[buffer-diff] Buffer diff benchmarks. Tests diff performance across buffer sizes (400-16000 cells), change percentages (0-100%), change patterns (scattered, clustered, row-based), DualBuffer operations, and dirty row tracking effectiveness.

[encoding] Encoding benchmarks for Sixel and Kitty protocols. Kitty is faster because it sends raw pixels; Sixel requires palette encoding. Use Kitty when terminal supports it.

[components-rendering] Component rendering benchmarks. Tests individual components, nested layouts, tables, lists, scrollable containers, and full page layouts. ANSI output generation is also measured.

[graph] Graph component and Mermaid diagram benchmarks. Tests parsing (flowchart, sequence, class), layout calculation, conversion to Melker XML, and full rendering pipeline.

[quantization] Quantization benchmarks. Median-cut is O(n*colors) and expensive. Fixed palettes are O(n). Cache quantization for static images.

[buffer-diff] Buffer diff benchmarks. Tests diff performance across buffer sizes (400-16000 cells), change percentages (0-100%), change patterns (scattered, clustered, row-based), DualBuffer operations, and dirty row tracking effectiveness.

[content-measurer] Content measurement benchmarks. Tests single element measurement, flat containers (10-500 children), nested containers (various depths), scrollable container fast-path optimization, and mixed element type containers.

[graph] Graph component and Mermaid diagram benchmarks. Tests parsing (flowchart, sequence, class), layout calculation, conversion to Melker XML, and full rendering pipeline.

[ansi-output] ANSI output generation benchmarks. Tests scattered vs contiguous updates, full screen rendering, style changes, color mode comparisons (truecolor/256/16/none), and span grouping optimization.

[components-rendering] Component rendering benchmarks. Tests individual components, nested layouts, tables, lists, scrollable containers, and full page layouts. ANSI output generation is also measured.

[graph] Graph component and Mermaid diagram benchmarks. Tests parsing (flowchart, sequence, class), layout calculation, conversion to Melker XML, and full rendering pipeline.

[buffer-diff] Buffer diff benchmarks. Tests diff performance across buffer sizes (400-16000 cells), change percentages (0-100%), change patterns (scattered, clustered, row-based), DualBuffer operations, and dirty row tracking effectiveness.

[tree-traversal] Tree traversal benchmarks. Tests findElement, hasElement, collectElements, isDescendant, findElementById, and findParentOf across flat trees (100-1000 nodes), deep trees (10-50 levels), and wide balanced trees (150-780 nodes).

[encoding] Encoding benchmarks for Sixel and Kitty protocols. Kitty is faster because it sends raw pixels; Sixel requires palette encoding. Use Kitty when terminal supports it.

[dithering] Dithering benchmarks for all supported algorithms. Ordered is fastest (Bayer matrix), blue noise is highest quality, error-diffusion (Floyd-Steinberg, Sierra, Atkinson) balance speed and quality.

[encoding] Encoding benchmarks for Sixel and Kitty protocols. Kitty is faster because it sends raw pixels; Sixel requires palette encoding. Use Kitty when terminal supports it.

[geometry] Geometry utility benchmarks. Tests pointInBounds, clampToBounds, clipBounds, and boundsIntersect at various scales. These are foundational operations used in hit testing, rendering, and viewport management.

[hit-test] Hit testing benchmarks. Tests element detection across flat trees (10-500 elements), deep trees (5-20 levels), and wide trees (150-1100 elements). Includes miss scenarios and interactive element checks.

[encoding] Encoding benchmarks for Sixel and Kitty protocols. Kitty is faster because it sends raw pixels; Sixel requires palette encoding. Use Kitty when terminal supports it.

[hit-test] Hit testing benchmarks. Tests element detection across flat trees (10-500 elements), deep trees (5-20 levels), and wide trees (150-1100 elements). Includes miss scenarios and interactive element checks.
